Award.AwardTitle: Computationally-Guided Manufacturing of Nanowires and Nanowire Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Semiconductor nanowires have unique properties that make them prominent candidates for the next generation high-performance electronic devices, chemical and biological sensors, solar cells, and photonics devices that can potentially impact every industrial sector. However, current technologies for producing nanowires are not suitable for commercial scale manufacturing. Because nanowires are often produced as an entangled mesh, complicated fabrication procedures are required to select, position, and align nanowires in placement required for making devices. This award supports research to investigate a novel semiconductor nanowire manufacturing technology that overcomes the above-mentioned obstacles. The research team will develop a unique and first of its kind technology for manufacturing nanowires with controlled dimension, composition, orientation, placement, property, and functionality necessary for large scale manufacturing of nanowire devices. The project will involve multiple disciplines including nanomanufacturing, computational modeling of materials synthesis, high precision control, and manufacturing system integration. As nanowire devices will find a broad range of applications in energy, healthcare, consumer electronics, and defense, results from this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society. In addition, the project will also help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research, increase impact on education, and increase public awareness of nanoscience and nanotechnology.

The enabling technology of the project is a laser-induced chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method recently developed at Purdue University. In this process, a laser beam is incident on a substrate, above which precursor gases such as silane and germane are heated and dissociated. Moving the substrate under computer control allows laser-guided growth of semiconductor nanowires with ultrahigh precision. The key to producing nanowires with dimensions of a few tens of nanometers is to utilize the interference effect between the incident laser beam and the surface scattered laser radiation. The research team will focus on computationally-guided manufacturing. It will generate computational models of the nanowire manufacturing process, and integrate them with advanced metrology tools, and feedback control in to a single manufacturing platform. As a result, this research will realize real-time control of the nanowire dimensions, properties, placements, and properties that is necessary for manufacturing nanowire devices at large scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop a computationally-guided nanomanufacturing technology for producing semiconductor nanowires with controlled dimension, composition, orientation, property, and functionality necessary for large scale manufacturing of nanowire devices. The main research activities and accomplishments include: (1) developed a computational model for computing the laser-guided nanowire manufacturing process, (2) developed methods to fabricate semiconductor p-n nanowires for making semiconductor nanowire devices, and (3) provided trainings to graduate and undergraduate students.

 

We developed a numerical model for computing nanowire growth which consists of two main components: (1) the non-linear femtosecond pulsed laser interactions with the substrate, resulting in substrate heating; (2) Heating of the substrate in a reactive gas flow environment, leading to nanowire formation. This complex, multi-physics model is capable of predicting laser based nanowire growth process with good precision, and was used for guiding the development of the laser nanowire manufacturing process. For the experimental implementation, the laser-direct-write method for nanowire manufacturing was developed and used to synthesize intrinsic and doped Si nanowires. We were able to fabricate p and n type nanowires and p/n junction which is the building block of electronic devices. Doping a semiconductor is crucial for device fabrication, but multiple and complicated fabrication steps are often required to obtain different doping concentrations and polarities. One unique advantage of our method is that the doping polarity as well as concentration were easily controlled during nanowire growth. The attached figure shows a p-n junction formed using laser directly fabricated p and n doped nanowires. Moreover, we have demonstrated nanowire based devices including sensors with high sensitivity. Thus, the overall merit of this project is the success in the development of a laser-based nanomanufacturing technology together with a computational model for guiding the manufacturing process.

 

This project also provide trainings to graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of numerical computations of advanced manufacturing processes and hands-on research experience in laser-based manufacturing of nanowires and nanowire devices. Undergraduate students played an important role for the proposed project as they participated in both numerical modeling and experimental development parts. The outcome of the project has also been incorporated into teaching undergraduate and graduate level classes. We also participated in the outreach programs organized by the Birck Nanotechnology Center of Purdue University, including NanoDays which is aimed at attracting high school students to STEM fields. Through these efforts this project has made significant contributions to education and human resource development.
